verses.text: At the window of my house I looked out through the lattice.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 7
rsbNotes.text: 7:1–27 This chapter is made up of three, possibly independent, parts, linked by the common theme of adultery. The first (vv. 1–5) and third (vv. 24–27) are in the form of instructions, and both warn about involvement with the adulteress. The middle section (vv. 6–23) appears as a dramatic narrative that functions as an imaginative reinforcement of the instruction.

verses.text: I saw among the simple, I noticed among the young men, a youth who lacked judgment.
He was going down the street near her corner, walking along in the direction of her house
at twilight, as the day was fading, as the dark of night set in.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 7:7
rsbNotes.text: 7:7 simple . . . lacking sense. See note 1:4. The lad is naive and unskilled in the art of living. The teaching of wisdom is aimed at such an impressionable type (1:2–4).

verses.text: Then out came a woman to meet him, dressed like a prostitute and with crafty intent.
(She is loud and defiant, her feet never stay at home;
now in the street, now in the squares, at every corner she lurks.)
She took hold of him and kissed him and with a brazen face she said:

rsbNotes.title: Pr 7:10
rsbNotes.text: 7:10 Seduction involves a deceitful show that attracts the victim while at the same time concealing the real intent.

verses.text: "I have fellowship offerings at home; today I fulfilled my vows.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 7:14
rsbNotes.text: 7:14 sacrifices. The food from these religious offerings provided opportunity for gluttony (Lev. 7:12–18). See 17:1; 21:27.

verses.text: So I came out to meet you; I looked for you and have found you!
I have covered my bed with colored linens from Egypt.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 7:15
rsbNotes.text: 7:15 The words are flattery, assuring the young man that he was specially chosen for this treat.

verses.text: I have perfumed my bed with myrrh, aloes and cinnamon.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 7:17
rsbNotes.text: 7:17 myrrh, aloes, and cinnamon. Aromatic spices used for perfuming garments and beds.

verses.text: Come, let's drink deep of love till morning; let's enjoy ourselves with love!

rsbNotes.title: Pr 7:18
rsbNotes.text: 7:18 take our fill of love. This is the most fraudulent proposition of all. To suggest that casual and illicit sex can satisfy deep longings for mutual, loving commitment is a destructive lie.

verses.text: My husband is not at home; he has gone on a long journey.
He took his purse filled with money and will not be home till full moon."

rsbNotes.title: Pr 7:19–20
rsbNotes.text: 7:19, 20 The woman is aware that this illicit relationship involves them in deceit. They vainly hope to avoid the jealous husband’s rage (6:33–35).

verses.text: With persuasive words she led him astray; she seduced him with her smooth talk.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 7:21
rsbNotes.text: 7:21 The seductive power of words is a constant theme (2:16; 5:3; 6:24; 9:16, 17). Over against this is contrasted the healing power of wisdom’s words (2:1–6; 3:1, 2; 5:1, 2; 7:24, 25).

verses.text: All at once he followed her like an ox going to the slaughter, like a deer stepping into a noose

rsbNotes.title: Pr 7:22
rsbNotes.text:
7:22 as an ox goes to the slaughter. The dumb animal is unaware of its fate and allows itself to be led.

as a stag is caught fast. See text note. The uncertainty of this line does not obscure the overall sense of the verse: the young man has walked into a trap.

verses.text: till an arrow pierces his liver, like a bird darting into a snare, little knowing it will cost him his life.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 7:23
rsbNotes.text: 7:23 arrow pierces its liver. A mortal wound.
